intro: [WRONG START] Galium californicum subsp. miggelense, commonly known as the coastal bedstraw, is a low-growing herbaceous plant native to coastal regions of California. It typically features slender, prostrate stems that are covered in fine, soft hairs. The plant produces small, white or pale pink flowers clustered in umbels, which bloom in late spring to early summer. Its leaves are opposite, ovate to lanceolate, and often have a slightly hairy surface. This subspecies is adapted to sandy or gravelly soils and is often found in coastal dunes or near the shoreline.
